Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Assessing Rural Farmers' Soil Management Practices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Agricultural nitrate pollution and subsequent contamination of freshwater resources pose a major threat to human health. High levels of nitrates in drinking water are often attributed to poor nutrient management practices on farms, where fertilizers leach into regional water supplies. Agricultural scientists have widely investigated soil management practices that can reduce nitrate pollution; however, effective practices remain underutilized among farmers. This project, which supports the training of a graduate student in anthropological methods, uses theoretical insights from economic anthropology to investigate the factors that affect farmers’ amenability to various soil management practices and implications for nitrate losses to freshwater resources. <br/><br/>This doctoral dissertation research focuses on farmers’ soil management practices among rural residential communities exposed to nitrates in drinking water. Specifically, it asks: how are agricultural soils managed when the people applying fertilizers are also those most exposed to nitrate-contaminated drinking water? To answer this question, the researcher will interview and work alongside farmers, shadow farmer assistance providers, and observe public meetings related to regional water quality. Findings will illustrate how environmental inequality intersects with socioeconomic mobility and community support to offer a deeper understanding of how communities of farmers negotiate the costs and benefits of resource management.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: This project examined the kinds of expertise that Latinx farmers bring to the problem of agricultural soil management in California's Salinas Valley. I explored the complex problem of regional agricultural nitrate pollution and subsequent groundwater contamination, where farm business owners are legally responsible for on-farm nutrient management and are benefitting from "free" fertilizer in the irrigation water. My study centered on a community of small-scale Latinx farm owner-operators, whose positions as working-class immigrants of color make them not only beneficiaries of poor on-farm nitrate management but also vulnerable to the health-related impacts of nitrate-contaminated drinking water. In this context, findings illustrate how farmers navigate regulatory burden as farm business owners while also formulating environmental responsibilities necessary for supporting the environmental health of working-class communities of color. This approach highlights theories and practices of environmental responsibility that are critical both of industrial activities and dominant state-led regulatory efforts.

Intellectual merit: While dominant efforts to mitigate nitrate pollution overly simplify who is responsible for pollution and who can and does contribute to water quality protection, the small-scale Latinx farming community inherently complicates dominant framings of "polluters" and "victims." Ultimately, these farmers demonstrate ways of theorizing and practicing extra-legal environmental responsibilities that are critical of both industry and state, and which are accountable to the complex ways in which their communities contribute to, benefit from, and are harmed by agricultural pollution. Findings from this study contribute to a growing body of cultural anthropological scholarship on struggles for environmental justice (1) in agricultural landscapes, and (2) that are critical of state-centric theories of environmental change. Furthermore, given the interdisciplinary nature of environmental justice scholarship, findings from my research are relevant to a number of other disciplines. Findings will be of immediate interest to social science scholars in the fields of geography and sociology, where interest in struggles for environmental justice overlaps with that of cultural anthropology. Additionally, given my focus on agricultural soil management practices, findings will support efforts among soil scientists - and agricultural scientists more broadly - to consider the social dimensions of environmental problems in agricultural landscapes.

Broader impacts: This project has provided valuable professional development opportunities for me while in graduate school and has provided numerous educational opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students who have benefitted from my mentorship through field days and research internships. Additionally, findings from this project are directly informing the way that agricultural technology transfer is done by farmer assistance organizations in California's Central Coast region, which encompasses the Salinas Valley and surrounding agricultural areas. I am currently employed by the Resource Conservation District of Monterey County and have met multiple times with staff to share study findings and to strategize the organization's agricultural technical assistance work with the regional Latinx farming community. Findings now inform the cultural practices of our organization and, through collaborations with partner organizations in the Central Coast region, inform broader regional efforts to support this community of farmers. Furthermore, findings shared through publications will inform agricultural technology transfer more broadly throughout California and the US. A subset of findings has been submitted for publication and is currently under review; this manuscript focuses specifically on agricultural technology transfer between agricultural technical assistance providers and small-scale Latinx farmers and other farmers of color. I hope that findings will prove useful to agricultural technical assistance providers across the US in developing more effective ways of collaborating with small-scale farmers of color.
